intro: Mitracarpus megapotamicus, commonly known as the Andean mallow, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Argentina and Chile. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its showy, yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and has hairy, lance-shaped leaves. Its fruit is a capsule that splits open to release seeds, and it is often found in mountainous regions. Despite its ornamental value, it is not widely cultivated outside its native range.
